Legal_Issue: Whether Procter & Gamble is entitled to an interlocutory injunction for alleged patent infringement
Evidence_Assessment: Affidavits from experts, lack of physical sample of accused product
Burden_of_Proof: Plaintiff must show: (a) serious issue to be tried, (b) irreparable harm, (c) balance of convenience favors plaintiff
Credibility_Factor: Court found Procter & Gamble's evidence sufficient to establish a prima facie case
Legal_Rule: Test for interlocutory injunction in patent cases
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged infringement of Canadian Patent No. 1,033,916 by Colgate-Palmolive's Ultra Fleecy product
Outcome_on_Merits: Not decided; injunction granted pending trial
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Parties had opportunity for cross-examination and submission of evidence
Key_Evidence_Considered: Expert affidavits, description of patented technology, market launch plans
Legal_Framework: Canadian Patent Act, principles of equitable relief
Applicant_Challenge: Proving irreparable harm without direct evidence of infringement
Court_Result: Injunction granted, maintaining status quo until patent expiry
Legal_Rule_Source: Common law principles governing interlocutory injunctions
Standard_of_Proof: Serious issue to be tried (lower than balance of probabilities)
Defendant_Response: Denial of infringement, challenge to existence of irreparable harm and lack of evidence
Outcome: Injunction granted, preventing sale of Ultra Fleecy until patent expiration
Decision_Authority: Superior court with jurisdiction over intellectual property matters
Remedy_Sought: Preventive relief to stop product launch pending trial
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Alleged unauthorized use of patented invention
Governing_Rule: Tripartite test for interlocutory injunction: serious issue, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
